column22: I understand a lot of the terminology after taking statistics and can identify specific sets of data that either supports or rejects the null hypothesis. I feel better knowing about p-value, degrees of freedom, confidence intervals, normality, etc.. Now when I read scientific journals I don’t feel so lost. Originally I was scared to take this class thinking it was a math heavy course. So I was pleasantly surprised when we focused mainly on the concepts and the math was the supporting factor. I think this helped me understand the formulas better than any other math class I’ve taken and helped to me succeed.
column23: I recommend going over checking conditions/assumptions. The proper conditions listed make sense, but I’d like to have seen an example in class of a graph that did not fit the conditions/assumptions. Of course, it depends on the study, but I’d like to see crazy graphs nonetheless.

column22: My confidence went up due to the professor's teaching style and helpful attitude, which helped me learn more and become more confident in my skills about statistics.
column23: As previously stated, more practice problems to learn how to use the equations and solve the problems properly.

column22: I feel I have a good foundation for statistics and reading graphs.
column23: I just needed more practice examples

column22: it went up definitely because it was my first time taking stats class in college and  feel like high shcool stats (AP stats) and college stats are different.
column23: it was amazing!

column22: Wasn’t sure what to expect before this class as this is my first interaction with statistics. Now having taken this class but not performing the best, I still feel the need further explore.
column23: Professor was nice and funny, which helped to bring topics to life. My different lab groups felt that our lab activities in R didn’t always go hand in hand with what was taught to us. It would have been nice to get all of the trouble shooting with installing R done quicker within the first day or two so we could have more time spend with the topics and let the concepts sink in. The simulations, anonymous google forms, and one no-stakes class game felt very interactive, and I wish they were implemented more.

column22: The concepts seemed less difficult and boring than I had expected.
column23: The course felt very fast, but that was because of the five week time period. I think that I should have studied more.

column22: I am not confident with technology use in general and stepping into coding is something that made me very nervous and anxious.
column23: A lot more practice questions than labs with other people that were also confused.

column22: I never taken a stats course before, so learning to code was actually fun. While it did stress me out it was a fun opportunity to learn some basics, even if I won’t be doing it again necessarily.
column23: Maybe had more hands on interactive lecture time working on problems as a whole class unit not just breakout rooms.

column22: I had a very surface level understanding of statistics and topics like Standard Error and standard deviation, as well as previously taking a biology course with a lab section all about using R studio. Stats 218 actually made me understand the mechanisms behind the code I was typing. I know now what R was doing with the data.
column23: I don't function best in an online environment, so maybe one method could be to randomly assign breakout rooms mid lecture to work on quick practice problems for maybe just 5 minutes could help with participation and engagement

My experience with this class has changed my perspective on STATS 218 I really enjoyed taking this class especially with having Professor Dermici as my professor.
